document.text: On Sat-., July 31, the Class of 1931 of Appomattox High School met at the Parkway Motel to celebrate the fourth r e u n i o n held by the group since their graduation the last one having been held five years ago. An informal  get-together at the motel preceded the ban quet which was served at 630 p.m. Frank Cawthorn of Peters burg, class president, presided over the meeting which was at tended by quite a few members, ex-Superintendent J. A. Burke and two members of the faculty Miss Kate OBrien and Mrs. Helene Welch Harvey. Reminis cences were exchanged and the class history was read with comments by Carey E. Carson, Jr. This was followed by a thumb-nail sketch,given by each member of the class, and the reading of letters from those who were unable to attend. Later, former Superintendent of Schools, J. a . Burke gave a most interesting talk on What Has Happened in Appomattox in the Last Five Years, in which he brought everything up to date. After his message, the meeting came to a close with plans for another reunion in the not-far- distant future. It was a most enjoyable evening for everyone present.

document.text: Meeting in regular monthly ses sion yesterday, the Appomattox County Board of Supervisors voted to postpone a reassessment of real estate in the county until 1955. The last reassessment was in the year 1949. Normally reassessments are made each four years, but the boards have authority to extend the period to six years. No action was taken last year, and yesterday the board voted to make 1955 the year for reassessment. The board also voted to renew its membership in the League of Virginia Counties, after a lapse of several years. J. A. Burke, superintendent of schools, appeared before the board and reported on progress toward a new elementary school building and a gymnasium at Appomattox High School. He advised that it is anticipated that bids will be receiv ed in early March on these two pro jects, which have been in the plan ning stage for over a year.

document.text: The Salk vaccine inoculation pro gram for children in Appomattox County who had their first doses last spring, will be resumed in October. Dr. H. E. Jenkins, Heatlh Director, said today. Notification has been re ceived from the State Health De partment that the countys shipment of the polio vaccine will arrive in time to give the inoculation in the period of October 1-15. The second immunization will be given the children who received the first dose last year, and to those chil dren only. At that time there were 409 children given the first dose and only those children are eligible to receive the second injection. The doses will be given without charge at the local health office with the assistance of community doctors. The vaccine is provided by the Na tional Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The Health Director urges the use of the vaccine because it has demonstrated its effectiveness and serves as a precaution against the crippling effects of polio. The family decision must be made at the time of the planned program, which starts in Appomattox October 3, at 945 A. M., when the colored children will be inoculated. The white children will be given the vac cine on October 4, starting at the same hour. The superintendent of schools, Mr. J. A. Burke, has made arrange ments for transportation to the Health Office. On the state level, new sources of supply for the vaccine are expected to make it .possible to enlarge the groups eligible for doses. It is ex pected that the work will setp up through the various grades to every Virginian up to the age of 20 and all pregnant women. Parental authorizations signed fox the first dose still will be accepted as valid. Parents who wish to can cel these authorizations will notify the Health Department or the teach ers in the schools.

document.text: Along with the rest of Virginia, Appomattox was blanketed under a heavy snow Tuesday night, wlhich blocked roads and main highways, caused the closing of schools for the rast of the week and brought busi ness to a stand-still. Whipped by a heavy wind, snow piled up in drifts several feet thick, and the average depth was twelve inches. Highway forces labored frantical ly to open roads, b l irdications were it would be late today before normal traffic could be lesumed. The roads east of Appomattox were blocked all day yesterday. Drifts on Route 460 between Evergreen and Pamplin harassed even stout high way tractors. Greyhound buses that got as far as Appomattox had to wait here for the day. Train- ran from half an hour to an hour be hind schedules until special ploughs attached to engines cleared tracks of snow. Those who got down town in Ap pomattox yesterday might have been in Finland as far as outside appear ances were concerned. Half the town business places were not open until late in the morning. Main Street was buried under a foot and a half of - snow and there wtere a  few drifts four feet deep. RFD mail carriers sorted mail at the post of fice but didnt leave the office.Nor were they able to make the routes all the way today. Fortunately the temperature was fairly mild and by noon yesterday the snow had begun to melt. One local bank was not opened until late in the day, and the other bank reptorted Ithalt Iby noon it had had two customers. Superintendent J . A. Burke, 1926 to date, The first public school house built with county funds was erected at Hurtsville. Other school structures were added as fast as funds from school taxes made these accomoda tions possible. Mr. N. R. Featherston, in his his tory of Appomattox County, re ports that the school term in the early days of the system was five months. Teachers average monthly salary was 25.00. In 1908, Professor Lindsay Craw ley was apointed principal of the high school at Appomattox. The frame building housing the high school stood on the lot where the present T. W. Moses residence is located. There were three teachers and 160. students. Funds allocated by the legislature in this year, with matching donations by private citi zens, financed the building of a new high school at the present site. Appomattox High School open ed in September, 1909, with the im posing name of Tenth Congression al District High School. Our public school system has made great advances in the years since 1909. In the past ten years alone, we have seen the construc tion of a new and up-to-date agri cultural vocational building at the high school addition of a hew gym nasium construction of the Carver- Price High School and elementary school for Negroes, and the build ing of the new elementary school in the town of Appomattox.
